Problem:
We explore a system governed by a complex-valued function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real-valued functions represented by the system of differential equations \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\), with A and B being constant real matrices. We investigate the effects of applying a Laplace transform \\( L{z(t)} = F(s) \\) on z(t).

If the Laplace transform is applied to \\( z(t) \\) resulting in \\( F(s) \\), and then inverted without any modifications or external influences, will the original function \\( z(t) \\) be exactly recovered?
Explanation: The Laplace transform and its inverse are theoretically perfect in recovering the original time-domain function when applied consecutively under ideal conditions. This presumes no modifications to \\( F(s) \\) and that all conditions meet requirements for existence and uniqueness of the transforms.
